conclusion: Determine the angle of deviation of the incident light relative to point D.
Triangle ABC is a right triangle with angle A = 90° and angle B = 60°, so angle C = 30°.
The light beam starts at point D on side BC, reflects off point E on side AC, undergoes total internal reflection at point F on side AB, and exits.
EG is perpendicular to AC intersecting BC at G. Point D is exactly the midpoint of CG.
Place A at the origin (0, 0), B at (a, 0), and C at (0, b) with angle B = 60° and angle C = 30°.
Using trigonometry, find lengths: a = b√3 and b = b/√3.
Position E at (x, y) on AC, coordinates of E are (x, x/√3).
The light beam reflects off E and undergoes total internal reflection at F on AB.
Angle of incidence at E equals angle of reflection; angle of incidence at F allows light to exit.
Angle of deviation is the difference between angle of incidence at D and angle of exit at F, which is 60°.
The angle of deviation of the incident light relative to point D is 60°.
